DOC.HEAD: Guerrilla Attacks Leave Six Dead in Colombia
DOC.TEXT: Guerrillas overran a remote town, stole $697,000 from a bank truck and battled an army patrol in separate attacks Tuesday in rural areas, authorities said. Six people were reported killed and three injured. The first attack took place in Surata, a northeastern town 280 miles from Bogota, police said. The town remained under the control of 50 guerrillas of the pro-Cuban National Liberation Army for several hours, according to the Santander state police. The guerrilla group concentrated the attack on the police headquarters, where it killed two policemen and seized weapons and ammunition, the report said. The National Liberation Army is one of the most active of more than 10 guerrilla groups operating in the Colombian jungle. In the southern area of Putumayo near the border with Ecuador, guerrillas of the Maoist Popular Liberation Army attacked a bank truck carrying $697,000, authorities said. The guerrillas killed two guards, injured three others, and seized two more before stealing the money and fleeing into the jungle, a police report released in Bogota said. Earlier, an army patrol in the Santander state was ambushed by guerrillas of the Colombian Revolutionary Armed Forces, said Col. Rodolfo Herrera, commander of the Colombian Army 14th Brigade. He told reporters that the patrol repulsed the attack and killed two rebels. The patrol was searching for an armed group that killed five emerald traders Monday and seized up to $142,000 from the victims, Herrera said. In another attack, gunmen killed a councilman in Caicedonia, 150 miles west of Bogota. A police report said it was not known if the attack was mounted by guerrillas.
